name: Onion Dosa
history: Onion Dosa is a variation of the traditional South Indian dosa. It involves adding a topping of finely chopped onions and spices to the classic dosa, which is a fermented crepe made from rice and lentils. This addition enhances the flavor and texture.
description: Onion Dosa is a crispy and savory crepe-like dish made from a fermented batter of rice and lentils, topped with a flavorful mixture of onions, green chilies, and spices. It's a popular breakfast or snack in South Indian cuisine.

instructions.title: Prepare Onion Mixture
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine the chopped onions, green chilies, cumin seeds, coriander leaves, curry leaves, and salt.

instructions.title: Make the Dosa
instructions.description: Heat the griddle or pan. Pour a ladleful of dosa batter and spread it into a thin circle. Drizzle a little oil around the edges.

instructions.title: Add Onion Topping
instructions.description: Sprinkle a generous amount of the onion mixture over the dosa. Press lightly with the spatula.

instructions.title: Cook and Serve
instructions.description: Cook until the dosa is crispy and golden brown. Fold and remove from the pan. Serve hot with chutney or sambar.

tips: Ensure the dosa batter is fermented well for the best taste.
Cook the dosa on medium heat for a crispy texture.
variations: Add grated carrots or capsicum to the onion mixture for added nutrition.
Experiment with different types of chutneys for variety.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed immediately. Dosa batter can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store unused batter in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat dosas on a pan until crisp.
presentationTips: Serve on a banana leaf for an authentic South Indian experience.
Garnish with a side of coconut chutney and a dollop of butter.
